reviewText: As a retired nurse I really thought a lot of the movie tells "it like it is". The scenes where a Code is in progress was realistic enough. The explanation about DNR status was real enough. Then it began to go a little "out there".  It has already been mentioned  that the main character is hooked on drugs. What amazed me were the scenes where  two other nurses at different times  had a drug to offer this guy. Please, who  wrote the screenplay,Nurse Jackie?  While it is true enough that you will find nurses  who abuse drugs, it has not been my experience to see nurses offering drugs to each other to "relax" a little while on the job especially.
expected more
Shows the strain on all nurses.
Good movie very realistic. My mother is an RN nurse and she liked it lot.
Excellent movie!
Exceptional. Watch if you or anyone close are in health care, particularly nursing
Wonderfully made movie that raises some important questions

Kayle (Leo Oliva-writer) is a veteran male ER nurse who pops pills to help him in his hectic routine. Floyd (Danny Glover) forces Kayle to instruct newbie Amanda (Casey Fitzgerald) who finished top in her class. Amanda discovers that things are more rigorous than expected. Kayle takes his job seriously, feeling for his patient's wishes over that of the family which creates issues.

This is a gritty well acted hospital drama that deals with the suffering and terminally ill.

Guide: No swearing, sex, or nudity.

I really enjoyed the movie, mostly because it hit on a subject I believe in strongly. The acting was good enough. This movie hits on a major controversy in this country. A right to die. I for one do not believe a persons DNR, should be allowed to be overturned by family members, for any reason. Now I don't believe a nurse should be making the decisions that was made in this movie, but, a doctor is another thing.
Great plot and interesting moral concepts.
Good movie, but the acting not so good
I work in an ER. This just wasn't very realistic to me and I felt like the acting was mediocre. But the story was OK.
Very average - not much plot. Disappointing in that I thought it would show more of what a third shift in the ER would be like.
Horrible movie. No real storyline.

An interesting film that takes a gritty, yet truthful look at what often happens to medical professionals (nurses) who so frequently work in a system with seemingly laughable checks and balances.  What helps the movie along is that the main character appears to be professionally trained as a nurse.
great movie

I didn't expect this film to be as good as it was, and it provoked discussions in our home. This was disturbing, but I think the topic should be talked about in our families...

The Shift does not reach even a poor Lifetime TV standard. But what it does bring to a viewer is to show what is seriously wrong in many public facilities, which is personnel bringing their personal issues and beliefs and angst into the workplace where they do not belong. The bordering-on-awful acting and the maudlin presentation does a disservice to the important issue of euthanasia as well as to the nursing profession. No, it did not make me "think" beyond how sad it is to see a fine actor like Danny Glover reduced to this level.
Though provoking.
It was intense at times.  I enjoyed it.
very good and very sad

This movie really shows the emotional struggle any medical employee goes through. It shows you that there is no TRUE right or wrong but only what you believe.

I like medical shows and if you like the new CBS show, Black Code, you will like this movie as well.  Really brings into puts out there the question of what ends would you go to in order to stay alive.  Since I personally have dealt with these awful decisions more than once, I found the movie interesting although I did not agree with a nurse taking the matter out of the patient's family's hands.

I thought the movie was realistic and a good fit for the actors. Sadly, many people in the helping professions become addicted to a variety of things, gambling, food, cigarettes, drugs, etc. It is the way they cope with the extreme stress of the job.
Loved it I would do the same for my family

This is a very realistic movie. We never know what decisions we will have to make in life regarding our loved ones when they become ill. Some may say it's a matter of good vs bad or right versus wrong. I will let God be the judge.

Raises meaningful questions and stirs reflection w/r/t life, quality of life, euthanasia, stress of medical profession, medical directive/DNR.....acting by some key cast members was only so-so, however - and the quality of the script did not match the potential of the story or the depth of the issues within it.
Lots of overacting, things that don't make sense and also don't compel you to make sense out of them. Like a Goodfellas with less plot and more docs.

As a nurse, I liked some of those points this movie hit. What especially struck me was the scene with the patient who was a former RN who had developed Alzheimer's and was clearly suffering. I have a hard time watching people suffer and as a nurse I feel that my job is to ease the suffering of patient's who are not capable of recovery. I've seen wounds like those and have heard and witnessed stories like this first had. Nursing is an agonizing job and there is a lot of different views on DNR, though the vast majority of nurses that I know agree with having one.
Even Danny Glover couldn't save this!

This movie is "fair", in my opinion, as it raises some good, though difficult questions for thought and discussion. Should children with terminal diseases who are mature in stature and awareness have some say in decisions regarding their end of life? And more....don't want to include anything here which might be a "spoiler". I stayed with the film because I'm in the medical field (caution: for others in the medical field, the "procedures" and interactions among staff are ridiculously bad, inappropriate and some just plain wrong) though the portrayal of procedures and interactions among staff are ludicrous and....please don't form your opinion about hospitals and their staff members from this film. It was also something to do while I was waiting to go to sleep. This is not a Saturday night fun flick. It's rather sad, but as mentioned before, it confronts some significant questions which more and more these days are demanding answers.

It was a really touching movie but the ending did not worked for me. Almost felt

Kept me on the edge of my seat. It was an incredibly moving movie.

As an ER Nurse, this wraps up about 3years of experience into one night. However, the physical and mental toll of caring for patient's and playing the game of live and death has major consequences of the emotional health of an ER nurse. Our training and background does tell our hearts and minds when patients 'should' live and die. "The Shift" opens your eyes to the struggles we face as healthcare professionals and the choices we make as humans.
This movie was interesting and PRETTY sad!!! Gave it 3 stars because it would have been a lot better without the added profane words
i didn't even finish the movie. so boring!
I wasn't impressed with this movie.  In fact, I'm not sure why I finished watching it.
A good movie, not great but good.

Not too bad. I'm a nurse, I understand these situations and the thought processes theses nurses are dealing with. I think anyone in the medical field would enjoy this movie.

This movie tells it like it is.  I myself told my whole family I want DNR and after what I saw on here, my family will be told it is My WISH It better stay that way and not to ever be changed.  I liked this movie, but just wish it would have ended telling the outcome of what nurse Amanda actually decided.

The acting is HORRIFIC, however...I gave it 4 stars because the story is spot on. I am an ER nurse, and it hit the mark in most areas. The CPR was ridiculous, no one compresses that softly, and we certainly don't do it on the side of the chest. But, like I said, the back stories amongst staff, the traumas in their personal lives leading them to their viewpoints, yep....real.

Good movie. It shows compassion for those who are suffering with no hope of ever having a normal life. It ask the question, what would you do if it was one of your love one suffering from a terminal illness. I could understand the doctor's decision in certain cases. It's a movie that touch on a very important issue people need to think about and discuss with family members at some point and time.
Kept me interested all the way through!

Thought provoking.  At what point do we allow people to suffer until the very end against their wishes?  We have seen it over and over again where the patient says DNR/DNI and the family decides to override the patient's wishes and prolong their misery with feeding tubes and artificial means simply because they cannot bear to see them go, and the eventuality is still there.  They increase their own misery right along with the terminal loved one's agony.

I'm a Danny Glover fan, so of course his acting was good.  The story was o.k. and the mercy killings were considered a grey area since the story portrays the killings as an act of kindness.  In real life, sometimes they are and sometimes they aren't.  Personally, I believe that when a patient is in agony with no hope for recovery it should be their choice and their choice alone to have a drug administered by a physician that would put an end their suffering.  The process of death can be a very inhumane and torturous journey; why make it any worse than it already is.

The movie could have been better since their was the potential for a hard hitting drama.  I gave it a three.
I found it slow at the beginning unable to finish watching it to give it a different rating
slow boring
I really enjoyed the movie. It would be a movie I would watch again.
It was clearly a film glorifying euthanasia... Disappointing... The actors weren't very good either.
A moving look at the ethical dilemmas posed by technology versus meaning of life.
This is one of those jobs Danny Glover is probably regretting. Writing was poor, behaviors of characters clearly bogus and I could not get through it.

I enjoyed this movie. I found it to be a fairly accurate portrayal of ER politics..... Specifically, the very personal struggle, for nurses and doctors alike, facing the reality of quality of life for patients and their families, who must sometimes make end of life decisions at a moments notice. If you have ever been faced with this kind of situation as a family, or as a medical professional, you too might find this movie interesting. It is a bit "old school" with regard to technology, but the basic principles apply.
Nice movie. Much better than expected for a pick a movie night.
Again, kudos for taking on the hard topics but make it MEAN something, ya know? What's the point in telling these stories otherwise? ;)
Thoroughly enjoyed this film!
Loved this movie ending was surprising
Hilarious. Do they not know where the heart is? Not on the right!  Pretty aweful...
I work in a hospital and I'm not too sure I believe this movie. I mean I know it's not a true story but I didn't like it much.
I expected a better movie. It was okay.....to much going on to follow.
I wish some of the storylines had of gone deeper.

I am an RN and face such ethical decisions everyday. I believe patients have the right to make their own medical decisions and they should not be overturned by family or anyone. What Kayle did however was take matters into his own hands based on his own ethical beliefs and that is wrong. For example when the mother did want her daughter resuscitated, then that is her right. She is the child's mother! The child is a minor despite what the child told Kayle. No-one has the right to play God. Thou shalt not kill. Excellent movie and acting.

This movie was a great insight into the life of nurses, especially ER  nurses. My ex was a ER nurse and have heard many a story from him. So this movie Truly  shows the inside of the Nurses life I feel. even though I'm not a nurse or caregiver I have watched relative's slowly  wither away from their family's blind decisions to keep them alive for purely selfish  reasons of their own. Great watch hands down.

no one knows how nurses feel about seeing prolonged agony of those suffering with no hope of recovery..as an RN all my life I know..I could never do this  but I can certainly empathize why he felt the way he did..Is it selfishness that keeps us holding on to our loved ones we just can't bear to let them go...however the bible says thou shalt not kill... very good movie..
This was such a poor movie!  The acting was terrible and so was the story.  Very unbelievable.
